message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and palpation findings suggest thyroid cancer. Among the options, only inactivating mutation of the p53 tumor suppressor gene is commonly found in thyroid cancer. MEN2 gene mutation is associated with medullary thyroid cancer, while RET gene mutation is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia. Calcitonin receptor mutation is not associated with thyroid cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest a thyroid carcinoma, and among the options, the most likely gene mutation to be found in this mass is an inactivating mutation of the p53 tumor suppressor gene. MEN2 gene mutation and RET gene mutation are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, while a calcitonin receptor mutation is associated with familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including hoarseness and difficulty swallowing, suggest thyroid cancer. Option D is the most likely gene mutation associated with thyroid cancer. MEN2 gene mutation and RET gene mutation are associated with medullary thyroid cancer, while calcitonin receptor mutation is associated with hypercalcitoninemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and presentation suggest thyroid cancer, and the most common gene mutation associated with thyroid cancer is an inactivating mutation of the p53 tumor suppressor gene. MEN2 gene mutation is associated with medullary thyroid cancer, RET gene mutation is associated with papillary thyroid cancer, and calcitonin receptor mutation is associated with medullary thyroid cancer but not commonly seen in sporadic thyroid cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and presentation suggest thyroid cancer. Among the options, only inactivating mutation of the p53 tumor suppressor gene is associated with thyroid cancer. MEN2 gene mutation and RET gene mutation are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, which has different symptoms and presentation. Calcitonin receptor mutation is associated with familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia, which does not present with a thyroid mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest thyroid cancer, and among the options, only inactivating mutation of the p53 tumor suppressor gene is commonly associated with thyroid cancer. MEN2 gene mutation is associated with medullary thyroid cancer, which usually presents earlier in life. RET gene mutation is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2, which can include medullary thyroid cancer but usually presents with other endocrine tumors. Calcitonin receptor mutation is not commonly associated with thyroid cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests thyroid cancer, and mutations in the p53 tumor suppressor gene are common in thyroid cancer. MEN2 and RET gene mutations are associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, which has a different presentation. Calcitonin receptor mutation is not typically associated with thyroid cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and palpation of a fixed and non-tender mass in the thyroid with cervical lymph node involvement suggest thyroid cancer. The most common genetic mutation associated with thyroid cancer is a RET gene mutation, which is usually seen in medullary thyroid cancer. However, the symptoms and presentation in this case suggest a more aggressive type of thyroid cancer such as anaplastic thyroid cancer, which is associated with inactivating mutations of the p53 tumor suppressor gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including weight loss, hoarseness, and difficulty swallowing, suggest thyroid cancer. Among the options, the inactivating mutation of the p53 tumor suppressor gene is commonly associated with thyroid tumors. MEN2 gene mutation and RET gene mutation are more likely to be associated with medullary thyroid cancer, which usually presents differently. Calcitonin receptor mutation may be seen in familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia but is not typically associated with thyroid tumors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests thyroid cancer, and among the options, only inactivating mutation of the p53 tumor suppressor gene is commonly associated with thyroid cancer. MEN2 gene mutation is associated with medullary thyroid cancer, but the symptoms and palpable mass suggest a differentiated thyroid cancer. RET gene mutation is another cause of medullary thyroid cancer. Calcitonin receptor mutation is not commonly associated with thyroid cancer.
